Award.AwardTitle: SMASS-Next: Next Generation Asteroid Spectroscopic Survey
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-0907766
Binzel

Dr. Binzel, two postdoctoral fellows, and students, will extend the ongoing Small Main-belt Asteroid Spectroscopic Survey (SMASS) to significantly fainter limits than previously possible. Key to this achievement is the use of a new NSF-funded state-of-the-art folded-port infrared echellette spectrograph on the Magellan 6.5-m telescope in Chile. The new instrument is expected to obtain spectra of near-Earth asteroids at diameters of less than 100m. The overarching goal is a better understanding of the connections between asteroids and meteorites and the clues they provide to the history of our solar system. Near-infrared spectra of some 120 near-Earth asteroids (down to less than 0.8 km in diameter) will be obtained and analyzed in a five-year program to explore the compositional distribution of the near-Earth asteroids. The results will be used to test the Yarkovsky effect (where heating of one side of an asteroid by the Sun can affect its orbit) and will help determine the origin of near-Earth asteroids (e.g., are they moved into the inner solar system by the Yarkovsky effect, or through collisions in the main asteroid belt?). The resulting insights will be critical to understanding solar system formation and evolution.

This work is expected to have an impact on the planning of future sample return missions to nearby asteroids by greatly increasing the sample with known compositions. It will also materially improve our understanding of the nature of potentially hazardous asteroids. The project includes the support and training of postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers, who will be involved in all aspects of the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF 0907766 Final Grant Report 

 Science Objectives for NSF 0907766, Richard P. Binzel (Principal Investigator):      (I) Explore the size-distribution of near-Earth asteroids (NEAs) for their meteorite link.    (II) Link the near-Earth asteroids to their main-belt sources.

FINDINGS – OBJECTIVE I:  Compositional Size Distributions

The near-Earth asteroid population shows a relatively constant distribution in the ratios of major taxonomic types over the range of a few km to 200m.  We have published a detailed compositional analysis in Binzel et al (2019; Icarus, accepted for publication).

 FINDINGS – OBJECTIVE II: Near-Earth Asteroid and Meteorite Links to Main Belt as detailed in Binzel et al (2019; Icarus, accepted for publication).

A) For near-Earth asteroid taxonomic classes [sample size of 1000 objects], we find a robust statistical link to main-belt sources:  S- and V-type NEAs link to the inner main belt, C- and D-type NEAs link to the outer main belt, E-type NEAs link to the inner edge of the main belt (e.g. Hungarias).  These robust statistics, derived using Bottke model source region analysis, is a new independent measure of the broad scale taxonomic stratigraphy of the main belt.  

B) For near-Earth asteroids for which we model their mineralogies to obtain H, L, LL probabilities [sample size of 300 objects], we achieve robust statistics for Bottke source distributions showing: LL chondrites have a predominant source from the inner main belt, H chondrites show a predominant source from the middle main belt, L chondrites show a possible source from the outer main belt.  

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2019
Modified by: Richard P Binzel

    Richard P. Binzel (MIT)

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: NSF 0907766 Final Grant Report Science Objectives for NSF 0907766, Richard P. Binzel (Principal Investigator): (I) Explore the size-distribution of near-Earth asteroids (NEAs) for their meteorite link. (II) Link the near-Earth asteroids to their main-belt sources. FINDINGS – OBJECTIVE I: Compositional Size Distributions The near-Earth asteroid population shows a relatively constant distribution in the ratios of major taxonomic types over the range of a few km to 200m. We have published a detailed compositional analysis in Binzel et al (2019; Icarus, accepted for publication). FINDINGS – OBJECTIVE II: Near-Earth Asteroid and Meteorite Links to Main Belt as detailed in Binzel et al (2019; Icarus, accepted for publication). A) For near-Earth asteroid taxonomic classes [sample size of 1000 objects], we find a robust statistical link to main-belt sources: S- and V-type NEAs link to the inner main belt, C- and D-type NEAs link to the outer main belt, E-type NEAs link to the inner edge of the main belt (e.g. Hungarias). These robust statistics, derived using Bottke model source region analysis, is a new independent measure of the broad scale taxonomic stratigraphy of the main belt. B) For near-Earth asteroids for which we model their mineralogies to obtain H, L, LL probabilities [sample size of 300 objects], we achieve robust statistics for Bottke source distributions showing: LL chondrites have a predominant source from the inner main belt, H chondrites show a predominant source from the middle main belt, L chondrites show a possible source from the outer main belt.
